comment.author: 59375758@N06
comment._content: This photo would have been taken somewhere just outside where one finds modern Eldoret township.   (Eldoret did not exist at that stage nor the Uasin Gishu farms.)  Please refer to my Flickr upload Ndalat.   Indeed the highest hill is Ndalat - sometimes written as Eldalat (in the early days) and indeed the Uasin Gishu Plateau  used to be written as the Guas Ngishu Plateau named.   Ndalat is the highest hill.  The one nearby is Kakeptui.   The caption does not read as "Mle" but as "Mts" - short for mountains.   In East Africa because the mountains are so high other high protrusions which in other countries would be referred to as mountains are referred to as hills.   The Turbo-Kipkarren hills and Sergoit Rock are visible from Burnt Forest.   The early explorers (and I would not hesitate to say other early travellers) would have used these hills as bearings.   Further in the background on clear days one would be able to see the Cheranganis and Mt Elgon.

comment.author: 59375758@N06
comment._content: Looking out towards the Turbo-Kipkarren Hills just outside Eldoret on the Eldoret-Kipkarren Road just past the junction of the Eldoret-Kisumu Road.   The tallest hill is Ndalat (sometimes spelt Eldalat).   I am interested in the identification of the other peaks.   This photo was taken in June 2009.

comment.author: 31575009@N05
comment._content: Extremely well found. Really great work. And thank you for your picture.

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: PigaPicha1: what a great contribution. I assume you are local? I was in Eldoret in 1987 and probably saw this view. The National Archives UK: thanks for adding to the Astonishing Power of Flickr group - a perfect example!

comment.author: 59375758@N06
comment._content:
I probably was a "local" from 1947-1962.   We farmed somewhere where those hills are located - just below the Sorora Hills.  (I do not know if the Sorora Hills are visible or not hence my request for others to identify the individual hills among that group of hills).   From 1950-1962 we farmed in Burnt Forest from where one could overlook the Uasin Gishu district and with it the collection of those hills as well as the lone Sergoit Rock and behind it the Cheranganis and Mt Elgon.   I was however an Eldoret local from 1950-1956 when I attended the Hill School, Eldoret as a boarder.  The new campus shown below was built after the tragic fire in 1951 in which Uganda pupil John Lattin perished.   You can see the Turbo-Kipkarren hills in the background and so you most likely would have seen them from Eldoret in 1987.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/59375758@N06/5513843387/]

comment.author: 66244718@N08
comment._content:
My familiy was raised on the arm (1946 - 1972) called Kakeptui that encompassed the Kakeptui Hills - we looked out on to Ndalat. The area was part of what was known as the Nandi Salient - our farm bordered the Nandi reserve
Great memories, beautiful people, beautiful land
